Comment: Not sure why your panties are in a knot.  OECD data sets are synthetic estimates.  Let's look at actual tax receipts.  Tesla is a prime example.  In 2022 they paid 0% on $5.5 billion in income, in 2023, they paid 1.5% on $3.1 billion in income, last year they again paid 0% on $2.3 billion.  In the last 3 years, Tesla's effective tax rate was 0.4%.  They are the king of tax loopholes.  My own company had an actual tax rate of 1.2% thanks to accelerated depreciation and tax breaks for stock options.  10% of the S&P 500 paid no income tax last year.  So we have statutory rates, synthetic effective rates, and then actual rates which we can extract from annual reports from public companies but even they leave out some nuance that requires the examination of the IRS filing.  In private companies, the tax loophole creativeness runs wild.
